awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Statistical Methods for RNA-seq Based Transcriptomic Analysis of Macrophage Function in Spinal Cord Injury
awd_abstract_narration:
Spinal cord injury causes functional impairment via the primary mechanical injury, followed by subsequent secondary injury mechanisms at cellular levels.  Most research has focused on understanding the mechanisms of secondary injury since it corresponds to functional deficits. Inflammation is a principal mediator of the secondary injury cascade, with macrophages contributing profoundly to the secondary injury.  Macrophages, one of the most important type of immune cells, migrate towards the injured spinal cord and engulf myelin debris that is generated at injury onset to form myelin-laden macrophages. In this project, the investigators will utilize RNA sequencing, a powerful method for analyzing global gene expression levels, and develop new statistical approaches to address biological questions related to how myelin-laden macrophages amplify inflammatory response and promote secondary injury. These studies will help researchers understand molecular mechanisms for spinal cord injury and shed new light on the treatment by targeting myelin-laden macrophages. 

This project aims to answer important questions regarding the mechanisms of secondary injury through the integration of new statistical methods and cutting-edge biological techniques. The central hypothesis is that myelin-laden macrophages in the injured spinal cord promote a local pathologic process and distal organ dysfunction. Specifically, the investigators will determine their molecular patterns and functions, study whether myelin-laden macrophages released extracellular vesicles (exosomes) carry microRNAs from myelin debris to recipient cells and then regulate their functions, and investigate whether these exosomes can enter the bloodstream and contribute to systemic inflammatory response syndrome and distal organ dysfunction. New statistical tools will be developed to analyze large datasets of microRNA sequencing and mRNA sequencing from multiple cell types and time points. In particular, novel robust statistical techniques are proposed to answer the following important questions: how to uniformly and robustly estimate large-scale gene expressions; how to compare them reliably across multiple phenotypes and measured across different platforms; how to accurately identify microRNAs' mRNA targets via sparse regression; how to use quantitative tools for studies of molecular mechanisms and comparisons of gene expression networks; how to control false discovery rate under general dependence; how to perform robust variable selection; how to estimate the size of spurious correlations.  The proposed methods will be applied to newly collected, as well as existing data to answer the biological questions related to spinal cord injury.  The project will integrate research and education by involving undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, creating new datasets, and developing publicly available software.  Students from underrepresented groups will be trained as part of this project.  The results will be disseminated broadly through presentations at seminars, conferences, and professional association meetings.

por.por_cntn:
Spinal cord injury (SCI) causes functional impairment via the initial injury and subsequent secondary injury mechanisms. One major issue is the persistence of myelin debris at the injury site, which arises from the breakdown of myelin sheaths immediately after SCI. Bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMϕ) migrate to the injured spinal cord where they engulf myelin debris, becoming myelin-laden macrophages (Mye-Mϕ). The mechanisms behind Mye-Mϕ formation and their functional consequences in SCI are not fully understood. Our study aimed to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying Mye-Mϕ’s functional changes and their potential implications. The following are the major outcomes of this project:

1. The pro-inflammatory disease-promoting properties and neurotoxicity of Mye-Mϕ in injured spinal cord

We demonstrated that Mye-Mϕ actively exacerbate the inflammatory response, hindering neuronal regeneration after SCI. These Mye-Mϕ densely accumulate in the injured core, occupying the epicenter indefinitely, leading to: a). Prevention of axon entry and growth, inhibiting remyelination; b). Loss of normal functions such as phagocytic capacity for apoptotic/necrotic cells and cellular debris, exacerbating the inflammatory environment; and c). Release of inflammatory mediators, triggering the neuroinflammatory cascade. 

All these consequences may impede tissue regeneration and functional recovery. Our findings suggest that Mye-Mϕ exhibit a unique activation phenotype with disease-promoting characteristics, posing a significant obstacle to neuroregeneration and wound healing. Targeting Mye-Mϕ and restoring their normal function could improve the spinal microenvironment and facilitate lesion healing.

2. Mechanisms of Mye-Mϕ in Regulating Microglia-Mediated Neuroinflammation

Microglial activation is involved in secondary SCI, but the process is complex and not fully understood. We have shown that microglia are in close contact with Mye-Mϕ in the injured spinal cord and remain chronically activated. It has been proved that exosomes can transfer proteins, mRNAs, and microRNAs (miRs) between cells, providing a novel mode of inflammatory regulation. Among these molecules, miRs have emerged as important regulators in neuroinflammation and microglial activation. However, little is known about the origin of miRs in exosomes and their functions in microglial activation. We demonstrated that a subset of myelin-enriched miRs is highly enriched in Mye-Mϕ exosomes. Microglia can extend fine, long processes to rapidly engulf exosomes. Moreover, Mye-Mϕ derived exosomes significantly promote microglial activation in cell culture and in the injured spinal cord.

3. Correlation Between Biomarkers Isolated from Serum-Derived Exosomes of SCI Mice and Clinical Outcomes

SCI can trigger systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), potentially causing distal organ damage. Exosomes, highly stable in circulating fluids, can be transported to distal sites within the body. Disease-specific exosomes isolated from the circulation can be used for disease characterization and prognosis. Consequently, exosomes released from Mye-Mϕ in the injured spinal cord may serve as biomarkers for SIRS.

To study the role of exosomes as serum biomarkers, we aimed to develop a high-throughput isolation method to meet clinical demands. Current isolation methods depend on large, expensive equipment and are laborious and time-consuming. We developed a MagPEG method that combines ExtraPEG and magnetic beads. With this approach, we successfully isolated up to 96 exosome samples from as little as 5 microliters of serum in 45 minutes. Moreover, DNA/RNA/protein purification and profiling steps can be seamlessly integrated into the isolation workflow. This high-throughput method for exosome isolation and molecular analyses can be used for sensitive biomarker detection from biological fluids. Using our MagPEG approach, we tracked and examined the release and distribution of exosomes from BMDMϕ in SCI mice, finding that BMDMϕ-derived exosomes were distributed in the serum, increasing as the disease progressed. These results may provide new insights into SCI-related SIRS and act as potential biomarkers for SIRS.
